In your future HTML you could consider marking all dates up with a [](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/time) tag. From MDN: >The HTML element represents either a time on a 24-hour clock or a precise date in the Gregorian calendar (with optional time and timezone information). It could look something like this: `

March 10, 2016

` It doesn't change the markup at all, but it does let you interact with any dates/times in you page in a predictable way using JavaScript.

As to your question on indentation: While the HTML specification doesn't require it and browsers don't care, indentation is very important to make HTML readable to humans. Here is what the [Udacity HTML Styleguide](https://udacity.github.io/frontend-nanodegree-styleguide/#indentation) has to say: >Indentation should be consistent throughout the entire file. Whether you choose to use tabs or spaces, or 2-spaces vs. 4-spaces - just be consistent! But the starting principle is that whenever something is nested inside of another element, you indent it, so that it’s clear where everything is in the markup’s hierarchy. ```html

The Headline!

A paragraph of text...More...

An h2 subheading

All paragraphs of text should be wrapped in a p tag

1Another paragraph of text...

``` And like you have done, you can keep inline elements inside of block level elements without creating new indentation for them: `

text...text...

`.

HTML does not have a dedicated mechanism for marking up footnotes, but has some suggested alternatives. For footnotes like this one the [HTML5 Specification](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/common-idioms.html#footnotes) recommends wrapping them in the [Aside](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/aside) (`
`) element. :information_source: From MDN: >The [_HTML
element_](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/aside) represents a section of the page with content connected tangentially to the rest, which could be considered separate from that content. These sections are often represented as sidebars or inserts. They often contain the definitions on the sidebars, such as definitions from the glossary; there may also be other types of information, such as related advertisements; the biography of the author; web applications; profile information or related links on the blog. Since this is a paragraph of text though, you really should wrap it in a

tag. But the

tag, it would wrap the whole thing, like so: ```html

1Garry Kasparov..

``` You can take a look at other [sectioning tags](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/sections.html#sections), like [
](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/article) and [
](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/section), which could be appropriate in this page.

I think that there is a fairly strong case to be made that this text is _emphasized_, and that the <em> tag is therefore more appropriate to use than the <i> tag. From [MDN](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Web/HTML/Element/em):

>The visual result is, by default, the same - both tags render its content in italics. But the [semantic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web) meaning is different. The <em> tag represents stress emphasis of its contents, while the <i> tag represents text that is set off from the normal prose, such as the name of a movie or book, a foreign word, or when the text refers to the definition of a word instead of representing its semantic meaning.
You got all the headings right.
It's easy to miss the superscript here, so great attention to detail!

The HTML [Deleted Text Element](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/del) (`<del>`) represents a range of text that has been deleted from a document. This element is often (but need not be) rendered with strike-through text. Think of <del> as an element you would use if you were marking up a document that had been edited several times. In that case <del> would denote text that had been deleted or replaced.

For a [semantically](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web) more correct solution, take a look at the [Strikethrough](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/s) (`<s>`) tag.

Great job including the alt attribute.

MDN has the following tips that you can consider:
>Omitting this attribute altogether indicates that the image is a key part of the content, and no textual equivalent is available. Setting this attribute to an empty string (alt="") indicates that this image is not a key part of the content, and that non-visual browsers may omit it from rendering.

But the [Udacity Style Guide](https://udacity.github.io/frontend-nanodegree-styleguide/#media-fallback) requires it, so it should be present no matter what.

According to the [HTML5 specification](https://www.w3.org/TR/html5/) the `<b>` tag should only be used as a _last resort_. In general, use the `<h1>` to `<h6>` tags for headings, emphasized text should be denoted with the `<em>` tag, for important text use the `<strong>` tag, and marked/highlighted text should use the `<mark>` tag.

Since this is "important" text (it's bold in the mockup) consider using the <strong> tag instead of the <b> tag.

Hi! Great job on the first heading. This exercise is all about using the [semantically](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web) correct HTML tags for the job, not about styling the page using CSS. All the styles in the mockup can be replicated using the default browser styles for existing HTML tag types. So when you get the tags right, the styling will also be right.

Here is what the Udacity HTML style guide has to say about [sematics](https://udacity.github.io/frontend-nanodegree-styleguide/#semantics):

>Use elements for what they have been created for. For example, use heading elements for headings, p elements for paragraphs, a elements for anchor, etc. Using HTML according to its purpose is important for accessibility, reuse and code efficiency reasons.

For instance, heading tags are [semantic](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_Web) in the sense that `<h1>` defines the most important heading and `<h6>` defines the least important heading (not the size of the text). Therefore it's totally appropriate that the articles headline is an `<h1>`. And it also looks just like the mockup.
